Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Structure and Dynamics of the North American Craton - An EarthScope Swath from the Ozarks to the Grenville Front
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is directed at improving our understanding of the lithosphere-scale structure of North America's stable continental interior (Midcontinent cratonic platform). The study area includes some of the world?s best examples of cratonic platform lithosphere structures. Specifically, it spans the Ozark Dome and the Illinois Basin (including the abrupt boundary between them along which the Precambrian/Cambrian unconformity displays over 7.5 km of structural relief), as well as the Rough Creek Graben and other major fault zones including the Wabash Valley Seismic Zone. It also crosses major Proterozoic sutures and the enigmatic Eastern Granite-Rhyolite province. The study is intended to address seven fundamental tectonic issues: (1) structure of intracratonic uplifts and basins; (2) Proterozoic assembly of the North American cratonic platform; (3) deep structure of intracontinental rifts and fault-and-fold zones; (4) lithospheric controls on intraplate seismicity; (5) deep structure of the midcontinent?s unusual anorogenic granite-rhyolite province; (6) structural and lithospheric controls on ?cratonization? of the North American platform; and (7) understanding the nature of the strong gravity and magnetic-field anomalies in the region.

The project is focused on operation of a three-dimensional, broadband, passive seismic array centered over the Illinois Basin. The array is embedded within the Earthscope Transportable Array, and is designed to provide enhanced resolution of subsurface structures in the region. The experiment involves deployment of 120 temporary seismograph stations over a 3-year period coinciding with the operation of the Transportable Array in the area; site occupation will roll in four distinct stages using a maximum of 60 simultaneously operating stations. The acquired seismic data are being analyzed using a variety of state-of-the-art seismic analysis tools: travel-time tomography using teleseismic P and S waves; wave-field imaging using industry-developed methods of stacking signals to improve signal-to-noise ratio and ?migration? of inferred seismic sources to their proper geometric position; and a detailed analysis of seismicity recorded on this dense array, to better locate earthquake sources and characterize faults. Estimates from previous work in the area suggest that approximately 100 local earthquakes and 12,000 mining explosions will be recorded during the course of the three-year field experiment.

The project also incorporates an integrated education and outreach component, involving: (1) in-service teacher workshops designed to expand the pool of master teachers knowledgeable about EarthScope science; (2) a teacher Research Fellows program to include high school science teachers in summer research teams; (3) involvement of students and the public in EarthScope-related activities using already established connections with schools, pre-college research symposia, and State Survey outreach programs (field trips; open houses; public presentations); (4) development of material for "Active Earth" displays for regional outreach, and for incorporation in widely used introductory geoscience textbooks; (5) engagement of undergraduate students through a Research Experience for Undergraduates program; and (6) graduate student education three research universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was directed at understanding the nature of regional scale earth structure in the midcontinent of the US.   The midcontinent has received little attention on earth structure under the incorrect notion that flat land without obvious topography created by active uplift is less interesting geologically.   Geologic investigations for over a century, however, had shown the region has complexity but most of it has been stripped to a flat surface by erosion.   We aimed to investigate large scale structure through the use the recent technology of "broadband seismic arrays".  These instruments allowed us to deploy and operate 140 temporary seismic stations in a swath running from Missouri to central Kentucky.   With these instruments we were able to record earthquakes from around the globe as well as local sources.   We used multiple methods for processing these data in combination with comparable data from the Earthscope Transportable Array with two different purposes:  (1) defining earth structure in three-dimensions and (2) detecting and locating seismic events within the array.   

Imaging results have produced several major discoveries.   

  1. The midcontinent can now be characterized as an area of mountainless roots.   Most continental crust has a thickness of 35 to 40 km.  Thicker crust is normally found only under area of active mountain building.   We found that much of southern Illinois has a crustal thickness of 60 to 65 km.   In areas of active mountain building this would normally be associated with mountains with elevations of 5000 m or more, but southern Illinois is flatlands with corn fields.   What geologic process created mountainless roots is an unanswered question.
  2. Our project discovered a previously unknown major crustal boundary along structures parallel to the Mississippi River between St. Louis and the confluence of the Ohio.   Crust west of that boundary is a more normal 45 km in thickness.  The anomalously thick crust in southern Illinois lies to the east ofthis boundary and defines an offset of approximately 15 km in the crust-mantle boundary.  The boundary is associated with a set of faults called the St Genevieve faults.  The sense of offset is the opposite from what would be expected normally.   In mountain belts the thickest crust is under the highest topography, but the Ozarks are on thinner crust but on higher than the flatlands of Illinois.
  3. Geologists had previously recognized an age discontinuity in (Precambrian) basement rocks in the central US they refer to as the Neodynium (Nd) Line because of that dating technique used.  Multiple lines of evidence indicate the Nd line is a major discontinuity that extends hundreds of kilometers in to the upper mantle.  
  4. Two lines of evidence link a structure in Kentucky called the Rough Creek Graben to a structure called the Reelfoot Rift that is the core of the so called New Madrid Seismic Zone.   A new continent scale map of the depth to the top of what geologists call "The Great Unconformity" clarify the link of these two structures.   The new maps clarifies an observation that has been known for decades.   Our results add a connection in the subsurface.  We found a major thinning of the crust under the Rough Creek Graben consistent with similar stuctures inferred previously for the New Madrid Rift.   These results invalidate an idea found in the literature that postulated the New Madrid Rift had three arms:  Rough Creek, St Genevieve, and an "Indiana Arm".  

Our results also have important implications for earthquake hazards in the midcontinent.

  1. We suggest the area along the Mississippi River Valley south of St Louis has an underappreciated seismic hazard.  We found seismicity rates in that area are comparable to a similar area in southern Indiana commonly called the Wabash Valley Seismic Zone.   The association of that area, however, with the large offset in the crust-mantle boundary discovered in this project may amplify the earthquake risk.   The St Genevieve Fault Zone has structures extending for hundreds of km, which are potentially capable of generating large earthquakes.   
  2. In contrast, we find the risk of earthquakes in central Kentucky may be minimal other than great earthquakes in the New Madrid region.   A careful search of events recorded by 12 months of recording in Kentucky uncovered only 5 earthquakes.  From that we infer the recurrence rate is roughly a factor of 100 lower than the rate in New Madrid.   

This project had a signficant education and outreach effort.  Major actiivities included:

  1. A series of secondary school teacher workshops held in collaboration with Illinois State University.
  2. Outreach efforts to landowners who hosted our instrumentation.
  3. The project supported PhD work by one student and provided partial support for two M.S. students at Indiana University.   A number of undergraduate students were involved in field work and independent research projects using data from the project experiment.
